questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the anatomy of the anal canal below the pectinate line?

choices.text: Lymphatic drainage is to inguinal nodes
Innervation is by the inferior rectal nerves
Venous drainage is into the systemic circulation
Tumors are more likely to be adenocarcinoma

questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma is more likely to be seen above the pectinate line. Tumors below the pectinate line are more likely to be squamous cell carcinoma. 

The pectinate line is at the junction of the upper two-thirds and the lower one-third of the anal canal. Developmentally, it represents the hindgut–proctodeum junction. The part of the anal canal above this line developed from the hindgut and the part below developed from the proctodeum.

questions.text:
Which of the following are not true regarding external hemorrhoids?
  1. Painful 
  2. Self-curing
  3. Banding is preferred
  4. Covered by squamous epithelium
  5. Commonly located at 3, 7, and 11 o’clock positions in the anal canal
questions.solution:
External hemorrhoids are painful, self-curing and covered by squamous epithelium. The branches of the superior rectal vein, located at 3, 7, and 11 o’clock positions in the anal canal are common sites for internal hemorrhoids. Banding is preferred for internal hemorrhoids. 

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, smooth muscle fibres, and elastic connective tissue. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types:

  • Internal Hemorrhoids 
  • External Hemorrhoids

Note: Repeated thrombosis leads to a semi-ripe black currant appearance of external hemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

questions.text: Which of the following will you not consider as a differential in a patient presenting with anorectal pain?
questions.solution:
Internal hemorrhoids are painless.

Causes of anorectal pain:

  1. External hemorrhoids
  2. Anal fissure
  3. Proctalgia fugax
  4. Levator ani syndrome
  5. Fistula in ano/anal abscess
  6. Inflammatory bowel disease
  7. Coccydynia
  8. Prostatitis
  9. Carcinoma anus/lower rectum

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of painless bleeding during defecation. On examination, a pinkish mass appears at the anal orifice when the patient is asked to strain. It reduces spontaneously when the patient relaxes. What will be the grade of this hemorrhoid?
questions.solution:
Prolapse with spontaneous reduction is suggestive of second-degree hemorrhoids.

On straining, a reddish mass as shown in the image was seen protruding out of the anal canal. It did not reduce spontaneously and had to be manually reduced. What is the grade of hemorrhoids in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, as the prolapsed haemorrhoids required manual reduction, it is suggestive of third-degree haemorrhoids.

questions.text:
In patients with which of the following conditions can injection sclerotherapy be ideally used?
  1. Prolapsed external hemorrhoids, not manually reducible
  2. Bleeding internal hemorrhoids
  3. Thrombosed external hemorrhoids
  4. Internal hemorrhoids, with spontaneous reduction
  5. Manually reducible external hemorrhoids
questions.solution:
Injection sclerotherapy is ideal for the treatment of first and second-degree hemorrhoids (bleeding or spontaneously reducing hemorrhoids).

1 to 3 mL of a sclerosing solution (phenol in olive oil, sodium morrhuate, or quinine urea) is injected into the submucosa of each hemorrhoid. Complications of sclerotherapy include infection and fibrosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe anorectal pain during and after defecation. The pain was present for 6 months but has increased in severity over the past 1 day. Examination finding is shown below. A per-rectal examination could not be performed due to pain. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the image are suggestive of thrombosed external hemorrhoids. Patients who present within 48 hours of thrombosis should undergo thrombus evacuation under local anesthesia. This procedure involves the removal of the clot with an elliptical incision on the skin.

After the initial 48-72 hours, pain typically plateaus and hence the patient is treated conservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath. 

Grade1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.

Surgery is indicated in: 

  1. Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids
  2. Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
  3. Early grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures

Surgical procedures used in the removal of hemorrhoids are:

  1. Open (Milligan–Morgan) hemorrhoidectomy
  2. Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy
  3. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy - is circumferential rectal mucosectomy. It is associated with reduced postoperative pain, faster recovery and shorter hospital stay 
  4. Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation

Open hemorrhoidectomy - Artery forceps are applied to the skin-covered external components of the hemorrhoid and traction is given to reveal the internal components. Dissection of the lateral pedicle is performed and finally, the pedicles are transfixed. Mucocutaneous bridges are left intact in this technique. The image below shows the procedure.

Closed hemorrhoidectomy - The hemorrhoid is excised with the overlying mucosa. The hemorrhoid is dissected from the underlying sphincter and the mucus defect is then closed. This technique is associated with higher chances of recurrence. This procedure is however quick to perform and less painful. The image below describes the procedure.

questions.text: What is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy?
questions.solution:
Urinary retention is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy.

Conventional hemorrhoidectomy(open or closed technique), is considered to be an extremely painful procedure. Dysfunction of the detrusor muscle or the trigone in response to pain or distention of the anal canal or perineum has been postulated as the cause of urinary retention post hemorrhoidectomy. 

Other complications include:

  • Fecal incontinence
  • Infection
  • Delayed hemorrhage
  • Stricture

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of chronic constipation,  blood-streaked stools, and pain during defecation for 2 months. On examination, a sentinel tag was noted at the anal orifice. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the presence of a sentinel tag is suggestive of chronic anal fissure.

An anal fissure is a linear or oval-shaped tear in the anal canal starting just below the dentate line extending to the anal verge. It can be acute or chronic. 

Chronic anal fissures last for more than 6-8 weeks, and are frequently associated with a triad of findings:

  1. Sentinel tag
  2. Hypertrophied anal papillae at the upper end of the fissure in the anal canal
  3. Deep canoe-shaped ulcer

Acute fissures are shallow tears in the anoderm. They are associated with:

  1. Anal pain
  2. Spasm
  3. Bleeding with defecation

The below image shows features of a chronic anal fissure

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common location of anal fissures?
questions.solution:
Over 90% of fissures are located in the posterior midline, with the rest being located in the anterior midline of the anal canal. 

The main hypothesis is that the posterior midline area may have decreased blood flow due to the configuration of the blood vessels of the anus. Also, the spasm of the internal anal sphincter may cause further reduction of the blood flow to the posterior anal canal.

questions.text: What is the procedure of choice in a patient with chronic anal fissure?
questions.solution:
Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice for chronic anal fissures.

Surgical therapy has traditionally been recommended for chronic anal fissures that have failed medical therapy. The aim of this procedure is to decrease the spasms of the internal sphincter by dividing a portion of the muscle. Approximately 30% of the muscle sphincter fibers are divided laterally using an open or closed technique.

The initial treatment of anal fissures includes:

  1. Frequent sitz baths
  2. Analgesics
  3. Stool softeners
  4. High-fiber diet

If conservative management with dietary changes and laxatives fail, other options including topical analgesics such as 2% lidocaine jelly, topical nifedipine, topical nitroglycerin, or a combination of topical nifedipine and lidocaine can be attempted.

Option A: Miligan-Morgan procedure is an open hemorrhoidectomy

Option C: Transanal resection is used to remove early-stage rectal cancers in the lower rectum

Option D: Altermeier's procedure is used for rectal prolapse

questions.text: Which type of anal fistula is seen in this image?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space between the internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. It is the most common anal fistula.

A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain. Anal fistulas can be simplex or complex fistulas.

  1. Simple fistulas- include a single tract, subcutaneous tract, and those that involve less than 30% of the external sphincter. They are easier to treat, and have lower chances of recurrence. 
  2. Complex fistulas- include fistulas involving more than 30% of the external sphincter, with multiple tracts, recurrent fistulas, and those associated with other predisposing factors, such as Crohn disease and radiation treatment.

Fistulas can also be classified into high or low-lying fistulas, based on their location with respect to the puborectalis muscle.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a history of discharge from the perianal region for the past 1 week. On examination, an external opening was seen at 2 o'clock position around the anal orifice. On per rectal examination, an opening was palpable at 3 o'clock position at the dentate line. What is the gold standard investigation for assessing this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of an anal fistula. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula.

Investigations available for fistula-in-ano are:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

questions.text: A patient presented with serous discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. According to Goodsall's rule at what position from the dentate line will the internal opening be palpated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of fistula-in-ano with external opening at 8’O clock position which implies that the external opening of the fistula is lying posterior to the midline. According to the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline. Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at a 6’O clock position.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline

questions.text: A known case of Crohn's disease presented to the clinic with a history of discharge from the anal region for the past 2 weeks. The patient underwent drainage of an ischiorectal abscess 2 months back. Clinical examination and imaging reveal the presence of a supra-sphincteric perianal fistula. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a history of Crohn's disease, recurrent anorectal abscess, and the imaging findings point towards a complex anal fistula. It will be managed using Seton's placement, which is done in two stages. 

A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. Setons can be classified as draining or cutting. 

Cutting seton

A cutting seton has been used as a staged fistulectomy, especially in high trans-sphincteric fistulas. After the seton is passed during the primary surgery, it has to be tightened at regular intervals, till it cuts through completely.

Loose/draining seton

In this method, the seton is placed to maintain drainage and create scar tissue around the sphincter so that its edges do not retract after cutting.

Option B: Fistulotomy involves opening the fistula tract and possibly dividing the sphincter muscle. It is very effective for simple fistulas with minimal sphincter involvement. 

Option C: Lateral internal sphincterotomy is a technique used for chronic anal fissures.

Option D: In fistulectomy, the fistulous tract is cut out completely.

Other surgeries for fistula in-ano include:

  1. Endorectal advancement flap- involves closure of the internal opening of the tract, debridement of the tract, and mobilization of anorectal mucosa to cover the defect. It is usually done for complex fistulas. 
  2. LIFT- Ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract involves identification of the internal opening with suture ligation of the intersphincteric portion of the fistula. The tract and infected gland are then excised and the wound is debrided with curettage. It can be done for both simple and complex fistulas.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of anorectal suppuration?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of anorectal suppuration is nonspecific cryptoglandular infection.

Anorectal abscess originates from an infection arising in the cryptoglandular epithelium lining the anal canal. The increased incidence of ischio-rectal fossa infection is due to poor blood supply.

It may also be caused by other reasons such as: 

  1. Crohn's disease
  2. Trauma
  3. Immunodeficiency resulting from human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection or malignancy (both hematologic and anorectal cancer)
  4. Tuberculosis
  5. Hidradenitis suppurativa

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of anorectal abscess?
questions.solution:
A perianal abscess is the most common type of anorectal abscess. 

Anorectal abscess refers to a collection of pus in the anal or rectal region. More commonly seen in men. There are four types of anorectal abscesses:

  1. Peri-anal (most common)
  2. Ischio-rectal 
  3. Inter-sphincteric
  4. Supra-levator

Treatment: Drainage of pus + Antibiotics

questions.text: A jeep driver presented with a swelling in the natal cleft, with pain, difficulty in sitting, and occasional purulent discharge from the area. Examination finding is shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Hair follicles are seen in the wall of sinus
Hirsute habitus is a risk factor
Commonly seen between the ages of 15 and 40 years

questions.solution:
The given condition is a pilonidal sinus. Hair follicles have almost never been demonstrated in the walls of the sinus. The hair projecting from the sinus is dead hair, with its pointed ends directed towards the blind end of the sinus.

Pilonidal sinus disease is a disease of the inter-gluteal region, characterized by the formation of a sinus in the cleft of the buttocks. It is more common in males between 15-40 years of age.

Risk factors include:

  1. Male sex
  2. Family history
  3. Being overweight or obese
  4. Trauma or irritation to the perianal region
  5. Occupations involving sitting for long periods- jeep/lorry drivers
  6. Hirsute habitus - thick body hair
  7. Poor hygiene

Sites involved:

  1. Natal cleft (most commonly)
  2. Interdigital cleft
  3. Face
  4. Axilla

Buttock friction and shearing forces in these areas allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can arise as openings, lined with granulation tissue and discharge.

Clinical features:

  • Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine
  • Abscess - due to a foreign-body-type reaction 

Treatment

  • Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area.
  • Abscess:
    • Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue and hair.
  • Surgical techniques: Bascom’s, Karydaki's procedures are for chronic pilonidal disease.

Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.

questions.text:
Which of the following is not used in the treatment of pilonidal sinus diseases?

1. Z-plasty
2. Limberg flap
3. Bascom's procedure
4. Incision and drainage
5. Surgical approaches along the natal cleft
questions.solution:
Surgical approaches parallel to the natal cleft, and not along the natal cleft are preferred, to reduce chances of recurrence. 

Pilonidal sinus disease treatment includes non-surgical and surgical approaches. The non-surgical approach includes conservative treatment with proper hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area. 

In case of an abscess- adequate rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are advised.

Surgical approaches for the management of pilonidal sinus disease include:

  1. Incision and drainage- for pilonidal abscess refractory to medical treatment
  2. Bascom's procedure- is a cleft lift procedure in which hair follicles parallel to the natal cleft are removed under local anesthesia
  3. Karydakis procedure- an ovoid area of pathologic tissue is excised parallel to the natal cleft and a fasciocutaneous flap is mobilized to cover the defect
  4. Limberg/ rhomboid flap- excises the pilonidal disease in a rhomboid shape and rotates a fasciocutaneous flap for wound closure
  5. Others- VY advancement flaps, and Z-plasty

The given image shows a Limberg/rhomboid flap done in pilonidal sinus surgery:

questions.text: An elderly female presented with severe persisting per rectal itching for the past 1 year, despite standard topical therapy. On examination, irregular eczematous lesions were seen at the anal orifice. Biopsy of the lesion revealed large vacuolated cells containing mucin. Which of the following is it likely to be?
questions.solution:
The given history and presence of large vacuolated cells (Paget cells) on biopsy is suggestive of Paget's disease of the anal canal. It is a rare intraepithelial adenocarcinoma. 

Paget’s disease is most commonly seen in areas with a high density of apocrine sweat glands, in elderly females. These can develop into an invasive cancer of the underlying apocrine glands.

Clinical features include intractable itching, burning, bleeding per rectally. 10% of the patients are asymptomatic. On examination, eczematous, well-demarcated plaque, with occasional ulceration and scaling can be seen.

On histology presence of Paget cells (large, vacuolated cells with mucin) confirms the diagnosis. 

Treatment:

  • Treatment of choice- complete excision
  • Limited, noninvasive disease-wide local excision and closure of the defect with primary sutures or with V-Y advancement flaps
  • Invasive component- radical resection with abdominoperineal resection (APR)
  • Medically unfit for surgery - topical 5-FU, imiquimod, cryotherapy, or argon beam laser therapy
  • Recurrence- re-excision (as long as the disease remains noninvasive)

Note: Most common site of extra-mammary Paget’s disease – anogenital region > axilla > eyelid. Perianal Paget’s disease is usually associated with underlying visceral malignancy, most commonly colorectal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal?

choices.text: Proctoscopy is the investigation of choice
Most common presentation is ano-rectal pain
Most common type of anal canal carcinoma

questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common anal canal carcinoma. SCC > Basal cell carcinoma >Melanoma

The median age at diagnosis for SCC is 60 years. Patients most commonly present with bleeding per rectum. Commonly metastasizes to the liver and lungs. The most common site of lymph node metastasis is to inguinal lymph nodes. 

Risk Factors:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) (types 16, 18, 31, 33) infection 
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or immunosuppression
  • Smoking
  • Anal receptive intercourse
  • Sexual promiscuity
  • Anal intraepithelial neoplasia
  • History of vulvar or cervical cancer

Diagnosis:

  • Proctoscopy with biopsy- investigation of choice 
  • MRI- for local staging 
  • CT scan- to evaluate for distant metastasis

Treatment :

  • Nigro regimen- chemoradiation is the treatment of choice
  • If any residual tumor is left behind after chemoradiation, abdominoperineal resection (APR) is performed

8th AJCC: TNM Classification of Carcinoma of the Anal Canal and Anal Margin

Primary Tumor:
  • Tis - high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion
  • T1 - 2 cm or less
  • T2 - >2 - 5 cm
  • T3 - >5 cm
  • T4 - invades adjacent organ, e.g. vagina, urethra, bladder. (invasion of the rectal wall, perirectal skin, subcutaneous tissue, or sphincter muscle is not included as T4).
Regional Nodes:

Regional lymph nodes include mesorectal, inguinal (superficial, deep), superior rectal (hemorrhoidal), external iliac, and internal iliac (hypogastric) groups.

  • N0 - no regional lymph node metastases
  • N1a - inguinal, mesorectal, or internal iliac lymph nodes
  • N1b - external iliac nodes
  • N1c - external iliac nodes + N1a

Distant Metastases:
  • M0 - no
  • M1 - yes

Stage grouping:
  • 0 - Tis
  • I - T1 N0
  • IIA - T2 N0
  • IIB - T3 N0
  • IIIA - T1-2 N1
  • IIIB - T4 N0
  • IIIC - T3-4 N1
  • IV - M1

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with bleeding per rectum is suspected to have squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?

choices.text: Surgical excision with CO2 laser treatment

questions.solution:
Treatment of choice for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal is Nigro regimen/ chemoradiation.

A combination of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) with mitomycin C/ cisplatin is followed by external beam radiation to the pelvis with a minimum dose of 45 Gy.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about melanoma of the anal canal?

choices.text: Wide local excision is done for tumors with sphincter involvement
Staged by depth or thickness of melanoma lesion

questions.solution:
Anorectal melanoma is staged by the depth or thickness of the lesion.

Anal canal melanoma is more common in females. The tumor appears as small and polypoidal or large and ulcerating. Clinical features include:

  1. Anorectal bleeding, itching, pain, mass
  2. Tenesmus, and changes in bowel habits
  3. Mesorectal lymph node metastases
  4. Inguinal lymphadenopathy 
  5. Distant spread- to bones, lungs, and liver

Diagnosis is frequently made following hemorrhoidectomy or local excision of the perianal mass.

Treatment:

  • Tumors without anal sphincter involvement- wide local excision with negative margins
  • Large tumors invading sphincters- palliative APR 

Regardless of stage, 5-year survival rates for anorectal melanoma are very poor, averaging at about 6%. The median survival time following diagnosis is 12–18 months.

Note: Most common sites of melanoma are skin >eye > anorectal region
